Reviews.Title: Best In It's Class
Reviews.Author: GGobblin "GGobblin"
Reviews.Content: Bought this from Amazon about a month ago. Did A LOT of online and in store research looking for a 32"-40" LED TV.Looked at Vizio, Samsung, Sony, LG in addition to Panasonic.After a month - I'm very satisfied with my selection.If you have read the reviews on this model here on Amazon you will see overall very good comments.Have seen some silly complaints about short power cord, and have seen some about the wifi adapter(I'm using ethernet cable). And some average comments on the sound, but the major points of the TV are Great.There is one reviewer (C Reach) who claims to have gotten video settings online - THIS IS TOTAL BS. I HAVE SEARCHED AND SEARCHED - Does Not Exist.Below you will find a Pros and Cons list and my picture and sound settings. My settings were done using my eyes and ears no calibration equipment.Everyone's taste and environment are different, so these are what look good on mine. I will eventually test further with my calibration discs, but for those looking foe a good starting point from which to fine tune - this should help.PROS:Non Gloss screen reduces glareAmazing viewing anglesGood overall contrast and color qualityLow power consumptionSmart (Flat) input layout on backGood assortment of connections*  (*Component video needs to use the included adapter - no biggie)Price / Performance Ratio is BEST in ClassDNLA and Internet FeaturesBuild QualityNo Spotlighting from corners like the Samsung sets (That was a dealbreaker for me)Easy SetupCONS:Sound could be better - Sure, but is equal to or better than most in this classCould have more extensive picture adjustment settings, but has enough to obtain a quality picture.Remote should be Illuminated and have a dedicated Sleep button. (Many people will use this for a bedroom TV)Some complained about power cord being short - But I had no problem with this at all. (It is detachable)OVERALL I Give it a 8.8 out of 10.MY SETTINGS:Were set by eye averaging several different chanels and subject matter in a room with no light other than the TV.You will probably want to fine tune based on taste and environment. Keep in mind this was done without calibration software, but I'm in the industry and have color experience. Hope it provides a good base...PICTURE:PICTURE MODE: CustomBACKLIGHT: 90CONTRAST: 96BRIGHTNESS: 40COLOR: 40TINT: -3SHARPNESS: 75COLOR TEMP: NormalCOLOR MGMT: OffAI PICTURE: OnC.A.T.S: Off:VIDEO NR: OffADVANCED PICTUREBLOCK NR: OnMOSQUITO NR: OnBLACK LEVEL: Light3:2 PULLDOWN: OnAUDIO SETTINGS:BASS: +5TREBLE: -5BALANCE: CenterADVANCED AUDIOAI SOUND: OffSURROUND: OnBASS BOOST: OnVOLUME LEVELER: +2TV SPEAKERS: OnHDMI 1 in: Digital

Reviews.Title: *Not* WiFi-Ready--yet
Reviews.Author: FaceForRadio
Reviews.Content: This TV provides an excellent picture, with a very wide viewing angle (for an LCD). However...On page 63 of the manual, it says "The TV's internal software was designed to work with Panasonic's wireless adapter model DY-WL10." After trying three non-Panasonic wireless adapters just to see if they would work (they wouldn't), I purchased the Panasonic adapter, but, as the other reviewer discovered, the TV would not recognize the DY-WL10. Panasonic's Netconnect site covers only 2011 television models--nothing about 2012 models.When I called Panasonic Support today, I was told that, no, the DY-WL10 isn't compatible with any of the 2012 Panasonic models. The model that the support rep recommended is the DY-WL5, which isn't available yet; I can't find it on Amazon, or even on Panasonic's own site. B&H; Photo lists it for pre-order with a March 31st availability date. So, at least until that date, this TV cannot use a wireless connection.Backup plan: I used a powerline ethernet adapter to connect the TV to my router. The TV recognized it easily, and it works fine in my house. But, as with all powerline products, your house's wiring must be pretty good for it to work well enough for video transfer.[Edit 03/08/2012] As a commenter pointed out, the appropriate wireless adapter for this TV (and I assume all 2012 Panasonic WiFi-ready models) is the DY-WL20, not the DY-WL5. Of course, I can't find that model for sale either as of this moment.

Reviews.Title: Exceeded expectations.
Reviews.Author: C. Reach
Reviews.Content: Really great tv. Perfect size for my office/studio. Picture quality is excellent. I calibrated the tv using settings I found with a quick google search. Sound is ok, but as with most flat screens it lacks a really impressive on board audio set up. Xbox 360 games look incredible. I've been playing Skyrim and Battlefield 3 and am blown away by the picture.  I fired up amazon prime (through Viera Cast) and watched Troll Hunter in HD. Again, beautiful picture (and awesome low budget Norweigian movie).And now a more niche consideration. I am an illustrator by trade and use a Wacom tablet and photoshop in my day to day work.  I purchased this tv with the intention of utilizing it as a third, large scale monitor for certain projects. A big reason I went for this particular tv is the LED screen. I find it is much easier on my eyes when I am painting on screen for hours on end.So there you have it. Beautiful image quality, a decent service lineup (Netflix, Prime, etc.), customization,  great aesthetics,  light weight, and it won't make your eyes bleed when you are painting an event poster at 2 in the morning.And yes, it says wi-fi ready but it needs an adapter. Otherwise it would say built in wi-fi. so the option is either buy a tv with built in (an extra $200-$2000) or buy an adapter ($60.. I agree it's a rip off. I ran a wire.). Same reason the E3 model had only 4 stars, from what I read in the reviews.  So if you can get past that, this is a really excellent buy.

Reviews.Title: Picture Looks Washed Out
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: After spending several days looking at different TV's, we decided on this 42" Panasonic LED LCD.  I am an electrical engineer and I understand the difference between an traditional LCD and an LED LCD.  I liked the lower power usage and light weight of this TV.  I have also had a Panasonic TV (tube type) for over 15 years and it still looks great. Consequently, I had a high degree of confidence with Panasonic.  Unfortunately, the picture on this TV seems washed out.  The darkest dark value is really grey.  I tried changing the settings as much as possible and it never really made a difference that was acceptable.  Also, I found we were pegging out the operating variables such as backlight, contrast, brightness, and others in trying to improve the picture.  I tried many different combinations and we just could not improve the sense that the picture was washed out.  Also, I have to wonder whether a TV is worth buying if you have to do so much adjustment to its default settings to get an acceptable picture.  Unfortunately, this TV is going back to Amazon.  I am glad we purchased it from Amazon directly so we got the 30 day return guarantee.  We will return it immediately.Update:  We bought an LG 47" LED LCD TV after we returned this one.  Beyond the fact that it is bigger than this TV, one thing to note is that the picture was much better--no washed out look to it.  This was with the default settings, not after extensive adjustments as was needed with the Panasonic TV.  We are very happy with the LG at this point.

Reviews.Title: Couldn's has asked for anything better!!!
Reviews.Author: Ray "RR"
Reviews.Content: I was initially inclined to buy a last year model tv, luckily I lag the TV purchasing process and came accross this puppy.It had the key features I wanted: LED, 1080p, and the viewing angle, and most importantly to have the right dimensions as it was going to be mounted on the wall.I was initially bummed out that  it was "wi-fi ready" rather than "build-in wi-fi", nevertheless, that issue was easily solve as I boughta thePanasonic DMP-BDT320 blu ray player that has "build in WIFI."The TV performs superb with the blu ray player and image is AMAZING! I havent even touch the color setting thus i know i am not getting the full deal yet.I will be buying the 37" model in the near future for family.Do me a favor, just buy the damn TV you wont regret it.{AUDIO ISSUE that exist "supposely"(EDIT)}AUDIO IN: Some of the reviews are innacurate about the RCA jacks. There is no direct RCA jack on the TV, HOWEVER, the TV comes with a special cable that once you plug it to the special jack it has, you will NOW have composite or RCA connections.This connection is for VIDEO/AUDIO in from another device.AUDIO OUT: The TV does have a Digital Audio Out. If you want to hook  up an older stero or other decive with Red/White RCA cable, you need to buy a "Digital Coax & Optical Toslink to R/L Stereo Audio Converter" which @ the low end should run you about mid $20, check the monoprice website (i buy all my video/audio needs from them).

Reviews.Title: Almost returned it!  Glad I didn't!
Reviews.Author: Meng Qi
Reviews.Content: My family always buys Japanese brands.  We have never been disappointed.  In fact we have had to repair only one product - a microwave made in 1997.  The "Add 30 Seconds" key became loose after 14 years of abuse!I bought this TV to use as a monitor.  At first I could not figure out how to solve the overscan problem (the edges of the picture are cut off, so the TV displays only a part of the picture).  So I almost returned it.  The solution is very simple.  Menu --- Picture --- Aspect Adjustments --- HD Size.  The default is size 1.  Just change it to size 2.My setting is Vivid, with some modifications:Color temperature: NormalBacklight: 100Contrast: 100Color Intensity: 60Brightness: 60Sharpness: 0Color mgmt: OnA.I. Picture: OffThe IPS-Alpha panel is great.  Sharp's panels offer somewhat better picture quality, but Sharp TVs are big and expensive.  For an affordable small TV, this is the best choice.  There is a competing product from Samsung.  Do yourself a favor and buy this TV or some other Japanese brand.The TV enhances blue and green color.  I am watching an anime called Squid Girl.  There is a lot of blue color.  It looks really good on this TV.The panel is made in Japan.  The TV is assembled in Mexico.Colors are natural and accurate.  Viewing angle is almost 180 degrees, as advertised.  There is no ghosting when playing games.There are only two cons, (1) no RCA audio out.  The only audio output is toslink.  I have to use a toslink-RCA converter.  Now the sound is coming out from a Sony SRS-DB500 2.1 speaker system.  (2) Playing computer games may cause more eye strain than a  monitor.

Reviews.Title: Cool Features but not Smart
Reviews.Author: Steve
Reviews.Content: This is my first HD TV (yes I know it's 2012 but hey TV is a low priority on my spending list), so I can't comment on the picture other than it looks awesome to me.I connect to a cable box and everything seems pretty responsive, changing channels isn't bad, ~2 seconds (I was worried about lag, at work there is a Vizio TV in the gym that I swear takes almost 10 seconds just to change channels. It's not connected to a cable box, so maybe there is a difference.)I'm a channel flipper so this was a concern.I connected the TV to the Internet via the Ethernet port, not wireless.. for me it was easy to just move my cable modem and wireless router near the TV. I've been through the "which wireless adapter will work" game with Tivo and didn't want to be doing that again, plus wanted to make sure streaming would be fine.So far, streaming from Netflix has been perfect.The Amazon site doesn't label the TV "Smart", but the Panasonic site does. I guess it depends on how you define Smart, but this TV can not browse the Internet or download apps, it can only access the five pre-programmed streaming services. Not a big deal to me though, I was just slightly misled.I was pleasantly surprised, when I clicked the Viera Tools and the DLNA option, it magically found my computer and I was able to play music and play a picture slideshow from the data on my computer. Kind of neat, not sure if I'll ever use it or not.Speaking of sound, I thought the sound from the TV speakers was pretty weak. From other reviews, I set Treble -10 and Bass +10 and that helps, but it's still not very good. I'm planning to add some speakers soon, probably the Panasonic speaker bar and wireless subwoofer when the latest one comes out.Overall I'm happy with the TV, awesome picture, the TV is beautiful, and it has a lot of features.

Reviews.Title: Great picture, lacks analog audio output
Reviews.Author: Gary F. "Garfy2008"
Reviews.Content: Like most flatscreen TVs today, the only thing I didn't like about this TV is that it didn't have analog audio outputs (RCA jacks). It does allow for analog audio and video input using a proprietary cable that plugs into their own jack. So I had to get a digital-to-analog converter so I could feed the audio to my stereo receiver. The picture is great just like my older 32" Viera I bought for my living room. The internet connection works without having to use Panasonic's own wireless adapter. What I did was use a Netgear wireless adapter that plugs into the wired LAN port of the TV (the TV won't know the difference that it's actually connected to a wireless adapter since it's coming into the wired LAN port). Now, according to most other reviewers, a wireless adapter connected to the USB port won't work so you need to make sure you get one that connects to the LAN port, not the USB port.

Reviews.Title: Nice TV for the price
Reviews.Author: katmax
Reviews.Content: We bought this TV as a bedroom set, for cable/DVD use, and for that purpose it is a nice buy (Amazon prime, no sales tax, free shipping, made it a good buy for us). However, one caveat, when we bought this in April, Amazon listed the specs as a 120 HZ flatscreen, we bought it based on this information, now the same set is listed as only 60 HZ, which is obviously a lesser quality product. This was a replacement for our much more expensive Sony Bravia, which developed terminal picture problems after only 3 years that rendered it unwatchable (FYI, another relative's Bravia is now doing the same thing, as is a good friend's, don't buy Bravias, or at least get long extended warranties for Bravia's, they don't last!!!) The default picture settings on this set are pretty gaudy, definitely need to make adjustments, we found configurations that now give it a much better picture than the default settings. I've seen other reviewers make recommendations for picture settings, I want to offer my choices, this combination of settings gives a darker, better contrast, with a more lifelike saturation to the color, along with a good sharp picture:  PICTURE MODE: VIVID  BACKLIGHT: +100  CONTRAST: +92  BRIGHTNESS: +22  COLOR: +33  TINT: 0  SHARPNESS: +20  COLOR TEMP: NORMAL  COLOR MGMT: ON  A I PICTURE: ON  CATS: OFF  VIDEO NR: AUTO

Reviews.Title: Pretty good TV
Reviews.Author: retiresoon
Reviews.Content: I am just a few days into using my 37" Panasonic, but will give first impressions.  I especially like the picture quality.  With some small adjustments for personal preferences, the colors are life like, rich, and sharp.  I do some graphics work and may use this for a computer monitor at some time, which is a plus.  Set up was easy and good documentation.  I think the compact design is slightly smaller than other 37 inchers I was considering which is good for my small TV space.  The Enerstar tag gives this an approximate annual operating cost of $9., which seems pretty amazing.Like others have mentioned, if you want to use wireless for internet movies you will need the adapter that costs $60 or so, or some other device.  It is slightly misleading in the way this is promoted in the product description.  The sound is thin to say the least.  The only sound out terminal is an optical out, which nixes using my old home stereo system like I had done with my previous set using RCA outs.  I've started looking for a simple relatively inexpensive sound bar that will use the single cord optical sound connection, but have not found anything yet.  So it looks like I'm stuck with the sound quality until I learn more.Compared to my old Toshiba that died after five years, the screen is sort of mat finish, but slightly more glossy and picks up more distracting room reflections.  Probably not a huge deal, but slightly different from my old TV. I suppose reliability is sort of a spin of the dice, but after having my last TV go south after five years I tried to find a brand with a low rate of repair and based on Consumer Reports and other reviews, Panasonic looked to me like it was among the more reliable brands.  I might have gone Samsung, otherwise.I'm not the most technically savvy person and may learn more later, but that's where I'm at now.  There are a number of features I will probably never use.  A nice TV for the money that could have been a great TV with better sound options and slightly less screen gloss.

Reviews.Title: Needs better audio out options!!!
Reviews.Author: Jvvolf1
Reviews.Content: Only one audio out (let me say that again) ONLY ONE AUDIO OUT AND ITS OPTICAL ! Could use an RCA audio out.

Reviews.Title: Good PC monitor.
Reviews.Author: vick1000
Reviews.Content: Bought this to replace a 24" professional grade IPS monitor, so that is what I will compare it to.First, over HDMI if you don't know how to manipulate your computer's settings, and the TVs settings, I would recommend you get a PC monitor for HDMI.There is no backlight bleed on the unit I recieved, none. There is however the typical IPS "glow" which is inherent on all IPS screens without special polarizers. I sit about 30" away from the screen, and it is hardely noticable unless I turn the lights in the room off, and a completely black screen is displayed. That is good. I would like to see a more uniform "glow", since there is none from the left while sitting straight on, only the right. This seems typical of modern IPS LED based screens, so just be aware it is present.Colors out of the box are HDTV colors, which means crap. I was able to get decent colors after lots of tweaking, and creating a specific profile in windows. Close enough for gaming, movies, and web browsing anyway. There is some light banding, but only noticable on test screens so far. A professional calibration with a hrdware sensor would probably solve the banding, but it is not of a concern to me.The TV is bright, rediculously bright if you want it to be. Since I sit in a dark room, 30" from the screen, I have the backlight down to zero, and brightness about half way. This probaby puts it around 100 cd/m2, which is my comfort zone. It also allows for extremely low black point and excellent contrast.HD content is emaculate, as expected. SD from my PS2 is very good, SD over the air, not so good. The aspect controls leave much to be desired, there is no 1:1 pixel mapping for SD content or other than 1080p resolution. The proper setting for your 1080p desktop is Full/HD size2.No 4:4:4 chroma mapping that I can find, not a big deal to me, I can deal with the occasional blocky/blurry test on the web.Response is typical of a modern 60hz display, nothing unusual here. Input lag is unperceptable in any mode on any label for me, but I am coming from a display with ~20ms of lag.This is a glossy screen, be aware.The bezel has a clear acrylic surround, which does not show up in the photos, making it a larger bezel overall than it appears in the stock photos. No big deal for me.The component and composite hook up is by way of a breakout cable, only one at a time, fine for my one SD source that is the PS2. 4 HDMI ports are more than enough for me.I use a reciever for audio, but this units audio is low compared to most other sets I have heard. Audio quality seems typical, with all the bells and whistles, I just can't comment on overall quality since all modern HDTV's audio are crap.Have not tested any of the networking functionality or streaming capability, that's what my PC is for.Overall and excellent PC monitor for entertainment purposes, provided you are not a novice. Color is tunable to an extent ( more in the service menu), blacks are excellent, low or no input lag, sufficient response time, and uniform panel/ backlight (on my unit). A worthy succesor to my old high end screen.

Reviews.Title: First Impressions
Reviews.Author: Veritas
Reviews.Content: I bought this TV 1 week ago to replace a very good TCL 32-in LCD-TV (purchased 2 yrs ago) that simply was undersized for my living room and thought I would provide some initial impressions.My setup:- OTA antenna connected directly to the TV- Windows 7 computer directly connected to the TV- Bluray player connected via HDMI to the TV- Old-school DVD player connected via component to the TV (not used regularly)- Ethernet cable connected to the TVI don't have a receiver or surround sound speakers connected, and do not have a satellite/cable connection.EXTERNAL APPEARANCEComing from an older-generation TCL (not the newer ones, which sport a thin frame), the Panasonic looks stylish and outwardly quite sleek. There is no glowing logo on the front, but the two-toned bezel, with a glossy 1 in black border surrounded by an even thinner clear border, gives this TV a very high-end look that belies the price. Of course, design is in the eye of the beholder, but I find the look to be refined and svelte. The side profile reveals how un-American this TV is in terms of thinness - only 1.5 in thick or so. Stand is nice, and overall the 42-in TV has a relatively small footprint and fit nicely into the space that once was occupied by my 32-in TV.INPUTSYou can read Amazon's included technical specifications regarding inputs, but in a nutshell, this TV has 4 HDMI, 1 digital audio out (Toslink, I believe), 1 VGA computer connector, 2 USB ports, 1 SD card slot, an Ethernet port, and this funky multifunctional component/composite port that requires the provided adapter cable to use (cannot use both component and composite simultaneously). Of note, there is NO 3.5 mm headphone jack included.INTERNET CAPABILITIESAs clearly stated in the included info, this TV is NOT a wireless TV - you must connect it via Ethernet cable to your router, or buy an overpriced USB dongle to enable wireless connectivity. There is also some confusion in certain reviews regarding the extent of internet capabilities, which I will demystify here. The only apps on this TV are Netflix, Amazon Prime, Cinema Now, Hulu Plus, and Vudu. Youtube, Pandora, etc are not included. You can connect to a DLNA-enabled server, and can also use your iOS or Android smartphone as a remote by downloading the appropriate app, which I have tried. Suffice it to say that while it is pretty damn cool to be able to control your TV with your phone, the interfaces are somewhat clunky with lag and do not properly harness the power of your phone (full keyboard, multitouch, anyone?).PICTURE QUALITYThis is what you most likely bought the TV for, right? I'll address each mode of connectivity in turn here.1) OTA broadcasts -I live in the Dallas area and pick up a lot of OTA channels, many of which are in HD (Fox, NBC, CBS, ABC, PBS, myTV, TXA 21, CW, several Spanish language channels, ion TV, etc.). Picture quality from these broadcasts is generally stellar, although there is some channel variability, which I think is more related to their feed rather than the TV itself. There is no noticeable motion blur, but I have yet to watch any significant sports programming (NFL football today).2) Computer input -This is where I do the bulk of my viewing, to be honest, especially since I don't have cable or satellite. I find it much easier to navigate Netflix and Hulu, as well as watch other videos, through my computer with a wireless keyboard than through the TV. I am currently connected to the TV through a VGA cable at 1366x768. On light backgrounds, there is noticeable horizontal flickering if you pay close attention; if you are engrossed in what you are reading, this will likely not be a problem, but is noticeable nonetheless. Also, at full screen resolution, Hulu does have some jarring motion blurring when the camera is panning rapidly. This may be a function of the refresh rate - folks with a 120 Hz TV can chime in with their impressions. Overall, some minor flickering and motion blurring on Hulu aside, I have enjoyed using this TV as a computer monitor.3) Bluray - I don't watch many movies through Bluray, but quality seems up to par with good colors and sharpness.4) Netflix, Vudu -Netflix reigns supreme in my house, and picture quality is excellent. The interface leaves much to be desired, especially compared to a computer interface, and this is where one's phone could come in handy if the manufacturers actually choose create a better user experience. In terms of Vudu, I rented a movie on Vudu a few days back, and in HD (not even HDX), the quality was terrific with no blockiness or fuzziness. Interface is decent, and you can watch trailers directly from the app. I haven't spent much time with Amazon prime or Hulu plus, as I don't subscribe to these services.5) SD card/USB -I haven't watched any videos through these inputs.I couldn't resist making a pros and cons list pertaining to image quality.Pros:- terrific HD picture resolution with good color output and contrast- solid computer monitor with minimal drawbacks- excellent Netflix and Vudu quality- LED "bleeding" is not really problematicCons:- more reflective than I thought - I would call the screen semi-glossy, as it is not like the mirrors that are some plasmas, but is also not a matte finish like some LCDs. May need to shut some of the blinds on a bright day, especially if you are watching something dark- viewing angles are not 178 degrees - there is definite degradation in brightness at more extreme viewing angles- minor flickering and some motion blur when in PC modeSOUND QUALITYB&W; or Bose quality speakers these are not, but they are more than adequate for typical viewing. I keep the volume in the 40s routinely and am able to comfortably here the TV. At higher volumes, it definitely becomes too loud for my taste. I think the surround sound mode only makes the sound more tinny and phone-like, but the base enhancing mode does its job. I wish the TV did include a 3.5 mm headphone output, however, as no TV speaker that I have encountered can match the prowess of some cheap computer speakers.RESPONSIVENESSTo answer Vince Vaughn's famous question as he talked about motorboating Jane Seymour's breasts in The Wedding Crashers, this TV is built for both speed and comfort. Changing channels OTA is very fast, especially compared to my previous TV. There is minimal input lag, and the internet apps power up fairly fast, although Netflix always starts with this annoying splashscreen offering a choice between "full" Netflix and Netflix for kids.REMOTEThe remote is fairly well-laid out, but there is no illuminated backlight, something that more TVs at this price point really ought to start including. There is a dedicated Internet input, but there are no configurable buttons to go directly to a certain input. There are also basic rewind/fast forward/play/pause functions included at the bottom, which work well with some of the internet apps. Unfortunately, the INFO button does not provide very much program information, and I have yet to figure out how to find a basic electronic programming guide that tells me what is coming up in the next few hours, something that my basic TCL included two years ago.Overall, I am very pleased thus far, and am giving the TV 4 stars due to the limitations delineated above. The reflectiveness was surprising given that this is an LCD TV, as was the lack of an electronic programming guide. But the picture quality, design, responsiveness, basic internet apps, and robust connectivity (despite no headphone input) have kept me happy thus far.

Reviews.Title: Limited web features
Reviews.Author: indy jay
Reviews.Content: Nice picture, easy set up, overall a great TV but overpriced considering that some features have been quietly removed. Specifically chose this model despite higher cost because of the Viera Connect feature that claims to allow access to YouTube and other web content. Spent over a half an hour on Panasonic support line only to learn that this particular model allows access only to paid content. It does not include Viera Connect despite what some reviews and specs say. If this feature is important to you, keep looking.

Reviews.Title: Finally!  A Flat Screen That Fits the Entertainment Center!
Reviews.Author: GT Rider "AP"
Reviews.Content: I have been pursuing a flat screen television since the FCC announced the requirement for broadcasters switch from analog, standard definition transmissions to digital, high definition.  Of course, the bigger the better except...I was told in no uncertain terms that whatever I bought to replace the CRT in the entertainment center had to fit in the same area of the entertainment center.As an engineer, I was able to use rusty math skills to determine the largest high definition screen in the 16:9 aspect ratio that would fit in the entertainment center would be 37" diagonal.  And that size is fairly scarce in the flat screen market.  Therefore, on size alone, this TV is a winner for me.Now for the technical evaluation, the likes and dislikes:Likes - It fits!  It fits!  It fits!The color is superb.  I have worked in the display industry for 12 years, so it is always a pleasant surprise to be given a product that needs little tweaking of any of its color profiles.  This is one of those products.There are enough inputs to account for just about any conceivable video input device... provided you like using HDMI.  Fortunately, HDMI has become the home video input standard in the past few years in spite of its shortcomings.  I was a little sad not to find an S-Video input since they have a composite video adapter.  It wouldn't have been that difficult to split the adapter cable to include S-Video.The iPad as a remote control is a remote control saver.  I don't know how, but remote controls have a nasty tendency to die in my house.  Using the Viera Remote application on the iPad is keeping the remote for this TV looking like new.  The only complaint I have about this software is that it can't be used to power the TV on or off.  Perhaps Panasonic might consider keeping the Ethernet port active when the TV is in standby (powered off) mode so that an incoming power request can toggle the power state.  That wouldn't be difficult at all to do since this TV uses the same command to power the TV on and off if my tests with the universal remote feature of the satellite receiver is any indication.  A firmware update and a patch for the software and the Viera Remote app or any home control system can completely replace the remote control provided with the TV.Dislikes - The control buttons for this TV are located on the back of the TV.  Not on the side, not near the side, but well into the back of the TV so that if I try to use them, I have to turn the TV in order to reach them.  Why is this an issue when the TV comes with its own remote control?  In my house, remotes die at an alarming rate - batteries leak, hand lotion gums up button contacts, Buffalo hot wing sauce corrodes button contacts, dogs use them as chew toys - you get the idea.  I would suggest to Panasonic to put the buttons on the side of the bezel, or on the bottom of the bezel where they are easy to reach.The audio just isn't up to par.  Sure, it has plenty of volume in my tiny house, but it is still pretty weak.  I can understand why others complain about this feature.  The speakers face the back instead of the front, where the viewer is located.  Dolby Surround for the internal speakers is wasted on these inferior speakers.  There is almost no bass response in these speakers as well.  Theatrical experiences should not be expected from these speakers.  If I had a receiver that accepted digital audio (TOSLink), I would use that instead of the internal speakers of this TV.Overall, I like this TV because in spite of it being built to an intermediate size.  Careful thought went into the video processor circuits to yield a crisp HDTV picture with excellent color.  The LCD shutters are fast switching so no jaggies or judder when watching HD content, in spite of only 60 Hz refresh rate.  It could be improved by relocating buttons to a more convenient to access location on the TV, better audio processing and speakers and a minor change to the Ethernet port and TV firmware to allow the Viera Remote application to completely replace the TV remote control.

Reviews.Title: Life-like
Reviews.Author: Money Leaker
Reviews.Content: The image quality on the 37" unit that I bought is gorgeous. You've heard the term "photo-realistic". The VIERA is "video-realistic"! I have HD digital cable service and the HD channels are nothing short of beautiful to watch. I also own a Mitsubishi 73" DLP and the picture quality on it is great, but the VIERA is yet MUCH MORE vivid & much more fuller of detail.Hardware & software setup are easy. One thing that most people will want to do is to ensure that C.A.T.S (Contrast Automatic Tracking System) is turned "off" in the software. Turn this "feature" on & off a few times and I think you'll agree with me that your viewing experience will be much more enjoyable with this feature disabled :-)I also would recommend getting the "Panasonic TY-WL20U Wireless Adapter for Panasonic 2012 Internet Ready TVs", unless you don't mind Ethernet cables (or are not going to plug this TV into the Internet). Bear in mind that this adapter is specific to 2012 models (at least, that is what I'm led to believe ;-)About the built in speakers. Let's be logical. Of course they aren't going to match aurally with what the LCD does visually. But they are serviceable. I bought this TV specifically for my mother who lives in a small apartment & doesn't have a HT system. Nor does she have an interest in such gadgetry. As long as she can hear Johnny Olson entreat the next lucky contestant to "Come On Down!!", she's happy.

Reviews.Title: I use this as my computer monitor.
Reviews.Author: Mr Wilson Phillips
Reviews.Content: I got this a couple of weeks ago and I am quite happy with it. I have my laptop connected via HDMI and it looks great. I had to turn the sharpness down to about 15 to get the text to really clean up, but it looks awesome now.I also rip my Blu-Rays to .MKV files on an external drive and watch them at my desk with Media Player Classic Home Cinema and they look very nice.This is an IPS screen and it has a nice wide viewing angle. An IPS monitor is also a necessity for photo editing. I have calibrated the screen with the http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00462PTDQ/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00 and I am ready to shoot some photos as soon as the flowers start to bloom.In fact, I like this TV so much that I ordered a similar model in 55 inch to hang on my living room wall. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00752R9SW/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_4

Reviews.Title: Excellent TV
Reviews.Author: Vin
Reviews.Content: We have had this exact model of TV (Panasonic TC-L47E5) for several months, and we're very happy with it.The picture is as clear as anything in its class. In fact, when my fiancee and I checked out this model in the store *right next to a Samsung*, it was actually clearer than the Samsung, which surprised us both. (We have a Samsung 32", which we love, so it's not like we have anything against that brand.)We're using using this TV with a Panasonic Blu-Ray player and Panasonic soundbar, and all of the components work well together. For instance, when I turn on the TV, the soundbar automatically turns on. When I turn on the blu-ray player, the TV and soundbar both turn on. Likewise, when I've been watching a DVD and I turn the Blu-Ray player off, everything powers down together.My fiancee and I are cord cutters, meaning we don't have cable. Instead, we use Amazon Prime streaming, Netflix streaming, and Hulu plus. This TV actually supports ALL THREE via its native interface. We have it hooked up to the Internet via an Ethernet cable (NOT wifi), and the interface and performance of all three services are faster than any other streaming devices we've tried (and that includes our Roku and our Panasonic wifi-enabled Blu-Ray player, even when hooked up via Ethernet). In addition, the quality of the streamed picture is OUTSTANDING... meaning it's WAY better than the quality of the picture that the same services provide via Roku.As for the sound, I haven't tried it without the soundbar, to be honest, so I can't comment on the TV's speakers. Just do yourself a favor and get a soundbar right from the get-go, assuming you don't have a home theater setup already. Reason: None of these thin TVs are going to provide you with rich sound. Period. I'm guessing this TV is no exception. That said, if you DO get a soundbar, I recommend sticking with Panasonic, so that it will turn on/off with the TV, when hooked up via an HDMI cable w/ audio return (as ours is).

Reviews.Title: Great unit....wireless works...with the "proper adaptor".
Reviews.Author: Ryan A. Spencer "bimmerfreak0"
Reviews.Content: You will see many reviews claiming this is a great tv. It is. The only flaw most can find is the issue with wireless connectivity. I would not disregard what they say because each of the other reviewers have mentioned a wireless adaptor that can be purchased separately from the unit and none of them work.Well folks, my adaptor works...5ghz Wireless N at that! It works great. Here's the caveat...the adaptor was the one provided with my Panasonic TC50ST30 plasma tv (2011 series). That tv was provided with the wireless adaptor...this television (2012 series) was not. For some reason it works...no hiccups or anything.Here is the model number: N5HBZ0000055[...]It looks like a really big USB drive...and it sticks out about 1/4" past the edge of the tv...nevertheless, it works and that's what counts.Otherwise, it's a great tv, great signal quality control, case design, options and otherwise.

Reviews.Title: Review of Panasoniv TV bought from Amazon
Reviews.Author: Richard N. Ragland
Reviews.Content: Panasonic VIERA TC-L32E5 32-Inch 1080p Full HD IPS LED-LCD TV This TV works great and has features I didn't expect.  I do have a bit of difficulty in connecting it to my existing home theatre system because of the inadaptability of the supplied cables.  That is because my existing system is so old. Still, I am extremely pleased with Panasonic.

Reviews.Title: Best Tv For the Price
Reviews.Author: Jonathan
Reviews.Content: Bought the Vizio 37inch with internet app, had to return it after 2 days. so decided to go with this one.so far loving this television,  used the WOW calibration Blue Ray disc and found that the picture is scaled. That means that you won't be using the full potential of your pixels, but not to worry tv has a setting to change that. Menu/Picture/aspect settings/ choose HD size 2..here are my settings...Light 80Contrast 60Bright 60color 52tint -7sharp 50!!Update-I Paid $560!!

Reviews.Title: It's a nice TV
Reviews.Author: conecrusher
Reviews.Content: Not a great TV, but a nice one. The colors are not as vibrant as on the Samsungs I have elsewhere in the house, and the viewing angle on the Viera is not that great. But, it does fit perfectly into a very tight spot, replacing a 35" tube TV in a built in cabinet that I don't want to modify.  it is one of the fw remaining 37" TV's that would fit in that spot.

Reviews.Title: I had to find out how good this TV is the hard way! (Don't buy the Samsung UN37EH5000 37" it stinks!)
Reviews.Author: JD "JD"
Reviews.Content: I wanted to upgrade my two year old Wal-Mart 32" Sony to TV a 37" but I was very limited in space since it was going into a built in cabinet in my home. I did lots of research and found the Samsung to be a option in a quality brand name unit. I purchased an Integra Blu-Ray player in order to make room for the TV since my old player was too tall to allow the TV to fit. Trust me I wanted that thing to work. After receiving the Samsung TV and making the necessary modifications to my cabinet I finally had my new Samsung 37" installed. I was sure to follow all the necessary setup procedures and did my auto channel programming. When the programming was complete I had 3 channels to choose from two of which were not in English! What the??? I had 27 channels with the Wal-Mart Sony! The Samsung model also sounds terrible! I know that flat panel TV sets have a tough time sounding good but this was ridiculous! I called tech support for Samsung and verified that there was nothing more I could do. I then took matters into my own hands and purchased a signal amplifier/splitter. That also did not help whatsoever.I returned the sub standard Samsung UN37EH5000 and I started to do more more research once again when I saw the Panasonic VIERA TC-L37E5 and found it too would fit and quickly purchased it.What a difference it made! The quality was much better! It sounded great and best of all I now had my channels back! The Panasonic also has built in internet capability to allow you to watch Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime etc. The owner's manual is an actual bound book not staples it is bound! The manual has 70 pages in English and 70 pages in Spanish. Easy to understand with all the info you need!Do your homework and check out the Panasonic you will be glad you did no more Samsung products for me!

Reviews.Title: nice TV easy set up..just one thing?
Reviews.Author: Steve
Reviews.Content: Don t forget to order the Panasonic wireless adapter, you will neeed it for wi/fi and no stores in town have it...

Reviews.Title: Simply gorgeous!
Reviews.Author: Michael A. Cartolano
Reviews.Content: The negative reviews on this tv posted here are probably the result of manufacturing defects that occur in ANY brand when anything is mass produced.  As a new owner I am hoping that my set is among those without defects.That said I am thrilled with my 37" set.  Everything is superb. Even the sound is better than average. I followed the settings posted here --the long list of settings and they are right on the money.  The picture is clear,bright and vivid.  I bought the wifi adapter and it worked immediately. There is no light bleed ; when the screen is supposed to be black, it is deep black.  The motion in this set shows no blur. Contrast is also excellent. All in all this is an excellent tv and I am very satisfied and I agree with all the 5 star ratings.I do hope that people will not be discouraged from buying this tv just because of a few negative reviews.  It is really a matter of luck and personal taste. Good luck folks!

Reviews.Title: Best 42 Inch 60hz TV You Can Buy.
Reviews.Author: J. Cabrera
Reviews.Content: I brought this TV in March and am very pleased with my purchase. I had to return the first one Amazon sent me because the reds were more pinkish than red (which is why I removed a star). Amazon has a painless return policy so it was no problem returning it. Love the fact that it's an IPS screen. There's no color washout at different angles, and color reproduction is very accurate. These are the settings I use:Picture Mode: CustomBack light: 38Contrast: 70Brightness: 40Color: 80Tint: 0Sharpness 79Color Temp.: CoolColor Mgmt.: OnA.I. Picture: OffVideo NR: OffAspect Adjustments: Full, HD Size: Size 2Advance Picture:3D Y/C: Off*Color Matrix: HD*Block NR*: OffMosquito NR*: OffBlack Level*: Light (antenna) Dark (HDMI device)3:2 Pulldown*: on* greyed out depending on video source

Reviews.Title: Precision Sharp Picture Makes This TV Seem Underpriced
Reviews.Author: Canis Majoris
Reviews.Content: For the price paid, even though I respect the brand Panasonic when it comes to TVs, my thoughts were that I would be getting an economy TV. Not the case. To my surprise, this as a comparable picture to the 2000$+ Samsung in the Living Room.Picture: 7.5/10Exceptionally good color, what you would expect from an IPS TV. Twilight blacks--though not deep void ones. Will be better than all LED TVs in its class with regard to blacks and colors.Viewing Angle: 9.5/10No noticeable washing out even when viewing at 180 degrees. From top to bottom is minimal.Portability: 9/10Weights around 30lbs and can carried around with leisure by anyone with above average arms. Goes well with most mounts because of the weight.**Note that this does not come with standard VESA holes in the back (the only screw in holes are 400mm x 400mm or 16" x 16").Accessibility: 8.5/104 HDMI ports. Yes, 4. No internet on the TV though what would you expect at this price? You can buy an additional adapter to change this.Thinness: 9/10Extremely thin at around 1.5".Other notes:-Turns on very quickly. 3 seconds give or take.-Feels well made.-HDMI ports are all on the left side of the TV; none in the back.-Power Cord is in the back towards the right side of the TV.Summary:For a smaller size TV where you want a picture to make up for the lack in viewing, this should be one of the few you look at for that purpose. With the price and IPS quality, this is a judicious choice for amount of performance for the price paid.

Reviews.Title: OK TV
Reviews.Author: IT Guy
Reviews.Content: Nice TV.  Set up in 10 minutes (stand assembly), no problems with configuration.  Good picture quality with a wide viewing angle.  Unable to program channels to skip, which for a channel surfer like me, is a big problem.  The sound's adequate, but I'll likely supplement it with a soundbar.I prefer the Sony Bravia's over-all quality but I'd buy the Panasonic again.

Reviews.Title: You get what you pay for.......
Reviews.Author: Gary
Reviews.Content: Good quality on the exterior with a good solid stand. The external surfaces have a shiney finish that reflects external light, which can be distracting. Picture quality is ok but is choppy with fast moving pictures, probably due to 60Hz. Sound is the biggest let down, appears very underpowered (tinny) so expect to buy a sound bar. But it is a low cost, albeit branded TV.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Buy
Reviews.Author: BBQ Cook "Ralph"
Reviews.Content: Great picture with wide viewing angle. Average to slightly above average sound quality.Big Surprise (at least for me): I have Cable TV but no set-top box.  The tuner in this TV is able to pick up 16 new channels that I never received before on my old non-HD TV. - I receive all my local TV stations in both HD and non-HD as well as 7 additional TV stations never before available.The only downside for some may be the remote control and extensive operator’s manual. I’m still, after a month and a half, having to look up info and make changes to some settings.BTW, I used the custom settings posted by GGobblin "GGobblin" (NY, USA) elsewhere in these reviews.  They were spot on for the best picture and sound.

Reviews.Title: Great Size for Bedroom
Reviews.Author: George "goze"
Reviews.Content: Great TV for the bedroom and to use it with Apple TV.  It is light and has a small footprint.  Picture quality is great and easy to use.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic VIERA TC-L37E5
Reviews.Author: George J. Abdallah
Reviews.Content: I'm basing this review on overall value.  Sure, if you compare this TV to a $3000-4000 55" Samsung or Sony, this TV is noticeably not as good... but that's a given. For a $600 37" TV, as another reviewer said, this is just about as good as it gets.  There is an LG set that looks as good if not better for hundreds of dollars more but, seriously, who wants to watch 3D on a TV under 40"?!?  I spent the time looking into multiple 32"-37" because I didn't want anything bigger for a spare bedroom.  This TV, with the proper settings, exceeded my expectations.  Out of the box, the picture is decent.  I found settings by another reviewer on Amazon (GGobblin) that made the picture much, much better.  I have this hooked up to a PS3 and DirecTV with Monster M2000 HDMI cables (good cables, EXTREMELY overpriced, I know someone who works for them that gave them to me - would never waste the money on them).I would definitely recommend this set for someone looking for the 32-37" max range.  Glad I came across this.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Television
Reviews.Author: David Kavic
Reviews.Content: Sips on power, 4 HDMI Ports, excellent TV.Use the AVS forums to adjust the color settings to your desired preferenceThis TV is fantastic for the price. The apps work well as well. IPS Panel works pretty good.I think for now this TV sets a solid bar/THE bar for this segment of the TV market.GET IT!

Reviews.Title: Excelent TV
Reviews.Author: Adan Saenz Jr. "Bettering self"
Reviews.Content: Replaced a Sony WEGA 42" LCD, had to lose the surround sound, and one dvd recorder due to hdmi connections only 4. Only bought a sound bar and hdmi cables so far. TV is great hooked satalite, blu-ray, media player with ease. Might have to lift tv thou as other reviews state for the tv remote to work if placed in front of tv, but no big deal. Base seams super stabble but I still have some wobble??? USB X 2 connections (sd card slots are also super to have my fav photos handy) are great have my fav music albums on this for easy accses. My tv sounds great I adjusted a few settings but need to have on 50 cant hear well with ac on, but I can't hear well anyway. Overall great buy, price is nice too even thou I want to get soundbar anyway, shipping was fast too. :>}

Reviews.Title: Great picture
Reviews.Author: T. Kaminski
Reviews.Content: After reviewing many options, I selected this television and couldn't be happier that I did. With just a few tweaks, the color looks amazing from any angle in the house. We use only OTA signals and the picture looks great! The remote is simple to manage with minimal intuition. I connected the television direct to my router via ethernet, rather than purchasing the wireless adapter, and am happy with the quality of Netflix and the ability to connect to my home server to play my music and videos. The Viera Remote app for smartphones is a cool idea, but mostly for the ability to share music, videos and photos from my phone to the television, since this model does not have more internet features.After having this television for one month, and having been able to compare it to tvs owned by friends and family, I can honestly say that I feel I got the best deal for the money.

Reviews.Title: disappointed..
Reviews.Author: Guy
Reviews.Content: Very disappointed with the tv.  TV was returned for a refund within 6 days after purchasing it.  A prior review stated the tv's picture looks washed out, I couldn't agree more.  No matter how much tweaking I did with the picture display settings, the picture remained "washed out" and weak looking.  When comparing the picture quality and colors of this Panasonic to my 40 inch Toshiba 40L5200U, the Toshiba easily blows it away.  If you're unable to comapre this Pansonic to another HDTV that truly has good picture quality, then you'll probably think this Panasonic is up to par.  But trust me, you're not receiving the highest quality picture display available.Although the picture and color lags in quality, Panasonic does a good job with the 'smart' and multimedia features of the tv.  Very fun to navigate and scroll through the different options this tv offers.  Also, absolutely 100% no signs of 'ghosting' on the screen.  Good job on that.  If you're not familar with the term, do a web search and type in "led ghosting".  TV gets a C as a grade.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic medium size flatscreen TV
Reviews.Author: Vinyl Rules!
Reviews.Content: As others have mentioned, this TV has a great picture. I'm somewhat of a video snob, with a professional-grade Panasonic plasma, so I'm critical in evaluating TVs and monitors. It's difficult to be critical of this TV. I won't go into details as many others have, but it's important to find the other Amazon review where the reviewer lists all his picture and audio settings. Wait, its more than important -  its absolutely necessary. The settings are so far out from the center point that it would take you quite some time if you did not have a calibration disk (DVE Essentials, AVIA, etc.) handy.  The sound is decent for TV speakers when using his settings.Also, the screen is non-reflective! this was a very pleasant surprise as this TV is in a room with many windows and bright sunlight.

Reviews.Title: Can you hear me now?
Reviews.Author: Fred W.
Reviews.Content: The picture is fine and the sound is awful.  I have had to order a speaker system because the TV's speakers make it very hard to hear dialogue, even with the sound turned way up.  I have a 27" Panasonic  flat screen and the sound is fine.  They need to do a better job with the TV speakers or include an additional set of speakers to match the quality of the picture.

Reviews.Title: Nice Product
Reviews.Author: Paul F. Lutton
Reviews.Content: Perfect size, very nice quality picture and sound, has the advantage of multiple HDMI imputs to allow several components being connected, would recomend.

Reviews.Title: Bought for my grandparents for xmas
Reviews.Author: Jeff Vier "boinger"
Reviews.Content: The love this TV a lot.  They tell me how great it is every time I talk to them.I wish I could be more specific, but I honestly have never seen it in person (I live 2500 miles from them).  I am only reporting their feedback.

Reviews.Title: Incredible display - Samsung begone...
Reviews.Author: Jason W. Miller
Reviews.Content: This display rivals the clarity of an XBR9 series Sony I have as my main entertainment display. Easily the most superb computer desktop display I have ever used, I cannot believe how crisp and bright and vivid this is. Also has an excellent, sleek physical form, with a clear bezel surrounding the frame. I had alot of trouble finding an appropriate 37" display as they are fairly sparse. So it was a bit of a labor to come up with a solution and I went through a few Samsungs (terrible, cheaply made and horrendous stands), but this one seriously nailed it. The price point was a little high for a 37" but so it goes for an uncommon size. It's like a whole new realm of computing now with this. I'm running DVI out from my video card to an HDMI adapter into the display. This will by default overscan the input as usually happens with PCs, so you'll need to adjust the size and tweek with a few other settings to get it perfect. But it will get perfect.

Reviews.Title: Good value, ...
Reviews.Author: Paul Solmon
Reviews.Content: I very much like the TV but Panasonic could do better with a firmware update.  The Only audio output is via optical cable.  That is not a real problem except the data format changes based on input and can't be locked to Dolby or PCM.  so every time I want to run the audio through the Onkyo receiver there are extra settings to change.

Reviews.Title: Great Buy
Reviews.Author: Scott
Reviews.Content: I was researching TVs for a long time and Panasonic wasn't really on my list at first. I was looking at the usual suspects like Vizio, Samsung, LG and just couldn't find one that had consistent ratings. I am restricted to the 37 inch size because of the cabinet I have. After then searching for 37" only, I saw the Panasonic models. All the reviews were very positive. The technical specs met all my needs (especially ARC).  I will note that the poor reviews with the sound and the lack of a built in wi-fi adapter are valid, but I have a home theater system and a wired ethernet connection, so that didn't concern me. Initial setup was simple and yes the standard picture settings are not optimal, so there's a bit of tuning to do. This TV is mainly for watching movies (streaming Netflix is excellent) but I also have an OTA antenna. There are a few stations that my old TV picked up fine but on this Panasonic are a bit choppy when the signal strength dips below 80. Overall, the picture is incredible. If you're looking for a TV with a lot of features and great picture you wont' be disappointed.Update: I was actually going to purchase a second one for my basement. However the price for the same TV is now over $140 more than what I paid a month and a half ago. So, generally when shopping for a TV, wait until Christmas or an upcoming sporting event (Super Bowl, March Madness). You'll find some great deals like I did. I can't bring myself to buy this TV again at its current price ($586) when I just got bought it NEW for $444.

Reviews.Title: was not a smart TV
Reviews.Author: michael mcfarland
Reviews.Content: the TV had only four apps, no more could be added.I felt that it was a smart TV from the advertising, but I learned otherwise when trying to add Pandora, and called the customer service rep.  returned the TV.the picture was very good however.

Reviews.Title: Viera TC-L37E5 37 inch TV
Reviews.Author: Larry
Reviews.Content: This TV has a stunning picture once set up with GGobblin's video settings. The only change I made was to increase the color to 60. It's a pity that the picture does not come set up this way out of the box, but with some effort, voila! It's perfect! The price is the same as the competing Samsung UN37EH5000 37 inch TV, but the Panasonic has WiFi capability with the extra Panasonic TY-WL20U Wireless Adapter / Netflix / Amazon Instant Video capability and 4 HDMI inputs vs no internet and 2 HDMI with the Samsung. Rare 37 inch size fits perfectly in my old AV cabinet. Very happy with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Bedroom TV for 34 inch width
Reviews.Author: H. Moorjani "indian dad"
Reviews.Content: Images are of decent quality. Easy to set up and use. Connects easily to wireless network. Netflix connection is seamless. Great value for the money.

Reviews.Title: Great TV for the money
Reviews.Author: Janet
Reviews.Content: I watched the sales closely and finally got this TV after New Years was over. I also purchased the wireless adapter device and it is well worth the extra cost. We are able to use our wireless network to watch HuluPlus and Amazon Prime. You can also watch Netflix and a couple of others if you have an account. The TV will also network with your computers if you want to do that although we have not done that yet. Some other brands mentioned difficulty with the wireless feature, but using the adapter we are able to receive with no delays or disruptions and our router is even on a different floor of our home.The picture is very clear. Color is good. We think the sound is fine.Unfortunately, the remote will not work with our cable network box so we still need two remotes. It is a cable box issue and not one with the remote. I bought a wireless keyboard to go with this TV. Don't bother with that. You cannot "type" into the search boxes and the mouse does not work like you'd use it on a computer screen. It is more difficult to browse Hulu and AmazonPrime directly on the TV than on a computer. Still it is really great to be able to watch these applications on the nice big screen and not on our computer monitors.I got this 42 inch version cheaper than two of the smaller screens which is why we purchased it. I was looking primarily at 32 inch because our living room is pretty small, but this 42 inch set was more cost effective and we really like it.

Reviews.Title: Love this TV
Reviews.Author: Schrammy
Reviews.Content: I just set up TV and aready love it!Great picture and easy set up.Looks great with PS3.The sound is ok but the picture quality far makes up for any sound quality issues.I used settings recommendd by previous reviewer and set looks great.

Reviews.Title: Best TV I have ever owned!
Reviews.Author: R. B. Meyer
Reviews.Content: An absolutely spectacular picture with wonderful sound.  I would definitely recommend an LED unit for anyone contemplating a new TV.  As far as I can tell, the picture quality far surpasses LCD or Plasma. Very easy to set up - the comprehensive manual was not really necessary, but may prove useful in the future.  If there is a down side, I was unable to connect to the internet with my router.  I could buy the adapter, but I won't, as connecting my TV is not that important, as I also have an Apple TV unit which does the same thing.

Reviews.Title: Excellent value for the price
Reviews.Author: Jean Liroff "wabanmom"
Reviews.Content: This was a present to my daughter and son-in-law who are both pretty tech savvy.  He tells me the setup was straightforward and easily accomplished.  Both report that the picture is fantastic and the audio more than adequate.  They noted the generous number of cable ports and the wifi ready capacity and were pleased about both.  The five star rating comes from them.  Neither of them imagines that I got this for $498 delivered.  I will allow them their exaggerated notion of my generosity.

Reviews.Title: Great for LED
Reviews.Author: btrvalik
Reviews.Content: Over all I'm very impressed - nice wide viewing angle, great color.  Animated movies like Tin tin looked almost 3D.. without all the side-effects of a 3D panel.  With that said, to me, all LCD /LED  seem to lack a little something compared to plasma's I own a 37" and a 50".  Plasma seems to have a little bit more warmth to it, image almost looks wet.  The low power consumption is great!

Reviews.Title: Great LED TV
Reviews.Author: HX
Reviews.Content: This is overall a great LED TV.Good:Price is reasonableIPS panel, wide viewing anglesGood overall picture qualityLow power consumption4 HIMI inputsBad:Low sound volume as most other slim TVsNo analog audio output, has to spend another $60 to purchase a optical to analog decoder.The power indicator annoys, it is on when TV is on and off when TV is standby. It should be a standby indicator, on when standby and off when TV is on.Customer service is bad. Tried to call CS for audio output inquiry, waited 20 minutes to be connected to a real people, and spent another 10 minutes to be asked all the registration information which I have registered through their website. The representative said that he is in technical support department and can't access registered information in website database. I am really confused that the product registration is not for support?

Reviews.Title: I love the panasonic brand.
Reviews.Author: George P. Glady
Reviews.Content: I have 4 Panasonic Viera TV sets And I am very pleased with each of them. I encourage my friends to choose this brand when purchasing a new TV.

Reviews.Title: Just what I Expected
Reviews.Author: John
Reviews.Content: This TV is exactly what we wanted.  The picture is fantastic - nice and bright.  The size (42 inch) is just right.  As expected, the sound is not where you'll want it.  But that is why they make sound bars and surround sound systems (the sound is not bad, just not great).  All in all - a great TV.

Reviews.Title: Awesome TV
Reviews.Author: Greencrocks
Reviews.Content: Very easy to set up.  Remember to purchase an additional receiver to use your wi-fi set up.  The program to set up is easy to understand and work through, and will still give you tips to what you can do to navigate quicker with the different buttons on the remote.

Reviews.Title: tc-l37e5
Reviews.Author: Rabbits Rafferty
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research before we bought this TC-L37E5. We like this TV a lot. The picture is non pareil. If I had a criticism it would only be that the manual is poor. That seems to be the case with consumer electronics generally. Notwithstanding the shortcomings of the manual set up is a snap, particularly if you're using HDMI. Buy one-You'll like it.

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: Robert V. Moore "wheeler"
Reviews.Content: Got this as a gift to my brother. He is extremely satisfied, and says it looks so much better than his old TV.  He says that the picture is extremely clear.

Reviews.Title: I am so happy!
Reviews.Author: LindaD
Reviews.Content: This TV is everything and much more than I expected. My grandson hooked this up and showed me lots of things I can do that I wasn't even aware of when I purchased it. I would recommend this product to everyone..

Reviews.Title: Solid buy for the money
Reviews.Author: J. Swartwout "Swarty"
Reviews.Content: We are pleasantly surprised by how good of a TV this is especially for the money we spent..  The picture quality is good, the sound is good enough (using it in our bedroom) and the smart features are everything we need (and much easier to use than I expected).  The only thing I think this lacks is a built in wifi feature but for $60 you can buy the usb plug in for it.  I already had an A/V person doing work on the house so I went ahead and had a cat 5 line run to it but for $60 the adapter would have been plan B.Great quality tv. Easy to use remote and easy to operate smart features a bonus.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic tv
Reviews.Author: Bobm
Reviews.Content: This television is as advertised-excellent picture right out of the box. No need to make adjustments, the normal setting is fine.My only negative comment is that the light adjustment mode makes it too dark a picture for the room that the tv is in. There is an "off" setting for that but then it becomes too bright in a dimly lighted room!I would highly recommend this to others. A very good buy.

Reviews.Title: Check the price / don't throw out the box! / a couple problems
Reviews.Author: Daniel Ford
Reviews.Content: Final update: I've upped the rating to four stars because I really do like the Panasonic despite the problems I've had with it. Plus the fact that the major problem was not the Panasonic's doing!I was very excited about this set because it fit exactly into the bookcase space available for it, and there was a short, easy run to my Comcast modem. Alas:1) The set arrived, and next morning it was priced well below what I paid for it. I requested a refund.2) The first assembly required was to attach a bracket to the base with four machine crews. I could not find them, so I went to the garage and carefully went through all the packaging outtakes. I found the four screws inside a fairly large plastic bag, secured in their own compartment at the bottom, so they could not be shaken out or even found by exploring fingers. Watch for this!3) One can't run an ethernet cord to the modem but must go to the router, so I had to order a longer cord. Worse, I got only black-white reception my DVD player with component video connection, and since the new telly has only the one component input, I can't use the VHS player at all. So I ordered a $90 player from Amazon in hopes that with HDMI input I will once again see color, and also that the VHS will give better results when it takes over the component video cords. Some of this of course was to be expected: technology moves on at an increasing pace.4) When the ethernet cord arrived, I still couldn't get an internet connection. Yet when I ran the cord to the new DVD/BluRay player, it was an instant connect. I conclude I got a lemon, and I am returning it for replacement.UPDATE: Guess what? The cord (also from Amazon) was defective. When the replacement telly arrived, I had the same problem, so I tried a different ethernet cord, and behold! I had an internet connection and could watch Amazon and Netflix movies, hurrah! (By this time, the original ethernet cord didn't work with the Blu Ray player either, so clearly it has a dodgy wire somewhere, that sometimes worked and sometimes didn't.So while I am still grinding my teeth over the problems I encountered installing this gadget, I am in the end very happy with it. So--four stars!

Reviews.Title: An outstanding PC/Gaming Monitor
Reviews.Author: Brant L. Rusch
Reviews.Content: As someone who had grown accustomed to using a 37" Monitor as a desktop display, it took some time to find a suitable replacement for a 6+ year old Westinghouse 1st generation Monitor that was finally showing signs of age (image retention in greys that did not go away, and the lack of color fidelity and black level found in modern LCD sets).As its primary use would be as a monitor, I needed a set that had minimal Input Lag.  This is the delay between when you move your mouse or, indeed, your gamepad (Xbox 360, Computer, PS3, etc) and the action on screen registered that movement.  This is not called out in  Television specifications and has nothing to do with motion-lag, refresh rates or anything of that sort, there are few places online where one can find out this information besides a dedicated group of enthusiasts and people doing trial and error.  When using a mouse, the effect is even more pronounced.The Panasonic IPS panels are considered to have some of the lowest input lag on the market, although this varies from year to year and indeed from model to model. I'm happy to report that this set achieves this goal.  I've tried other Westinghouse sets but the visual quality on them was sub-par, I've tried an LG32" set that when set up properly worked fine, but it was 32" and once you get accustomed to a certain size, any step down in size feels 'tangible'.  37" TV's seem to be a dying breed, and 42" in my use is simply too big (due to my seating distance).The one drawback that this set has is that the screen is not a flat matte.  Its not the mirror-reflection finish of a plasma, but it is not the flat matte finish of the average laptop screen either.  This may or may not be a problem for you.  Its not for me, but it should be noted.The nice part about this set is that, thanks to its adjustable options in the user menu's, you can tell the set if the HDMI inputs to receive a computer-standard color signal or an NTSC standard color signal (affecting the overall darkness of the image), and you can further tweak the image with a DARK or LIGHT gamma setting.  These adjustments are helpful to getting the most out of your available video signal, without having things appear to washed out or having too much 'black crush' (look it up).Since this set is LED, its thin, light and costs next to nothing to run.  My old Westinghouse was quite a display, it was on nearly every day for 18 hours a day give-or-take for nearly 6 years, and never gave me any trouble.  But being a first generation product its LCD panels began to fade and while it was still perfectly usable, its best years were behind it.This Panasonic more than fills the bill, updating my desktop with multiple HDMI inputs for other devices and a modern panel with popping colors and deeper blacks, all in a much smaller, much lighter form factor with the exact same screen size.  I'm sure in another 2 years we will be on to TV's in this size with bezels measured in the millimeters but that day isn't yet here, unless you opt for a 32" LG set with passive 3D which may or may not suit you.I'm happy with the purchase.  For PC or Console gaming its an outstanding choice with minimal input lag, and it makes a great monitor as well.JUST REMEMBER to go into the Advanced Picture Menu and change the HDMI mode from 1 (overscan) to 2 (pixel mapping).  Otherwise your windows desktop will be 'zoomed in' and the tv will be scaling everything.

Reviews.Title: Quality TV, Even If Internet Features Are Lacking
Reviews.Author: Ella Hill
Reviews.Content: I chose this TV because the LED panel is high-quality, there are lots (4) of HDMI ports, and it was on sale. Any TV is going to have its quirks and this one is no different. Here's what I learned:--Doesn't have a headphone jack. The description says there's 1 audio line-in (mini-phone stereo 3.5 mm) jack but it's incorrect. There isn't an analog audio out either. This means you could run into problems hooking up older speakers unless you get a digital to analog converter.--Short power cord (but it's detachable): it's about 5 ft long. Radioshack carries standard 6 ft ones, but we needed something longer and got this Startech 10 ft laptop power cord which has worked out great.--Internet: It's "wifi ready" but you have to buy a separate adapter. You can hook it up to the internet using an ethernet cable, though. We moved it to a corner with ethernet as a test, but the whole "Viera Connect" experience is pretty clunky. For less than the cost of a really long ethernet cable, a powerline adapter, or Panasonic's wifi adapter you can just buy a Roku which has more features/apps, an easier interface, and customer support if you need it.--Still troubleshooting: Doesn't play well with Zvox Z-Base 320 speakers. Somehow the TV overrides the speakers' standby mode and so when you turn the TV off, it completely powers down the speakers. To turn the speakers back on, you have to use the toggle switch at the back of the unit (no power to pick up remote signal).OTHER INFO--Power Consumption: 46 W--Stand dimensions (useful if shopping for sound bars): Base is 9.8" deep total and sticks out 3.8" in front of the screen. It's 15.8" long and it raises the TV 1.8" higher.--Jack locations: If you're watching TV, the input/output connections are on the left.--Panasonic has an augmented reality app on their website ("Panasonic AR Setup Simulator") that lets you see what various size TVs would look like in your room. It's pretty useful if you're trying to decide between "big" and "too big."OVERALL: 4 stars because it works great as a TV (excellent picture quality as others have mentioned). I only subtracted 1 star for the issues mentioned above because they were easy to fix and are experienced with most TVs. I would recommend this TV if you have an Apple TV/Roku/XBox. If you're looking for a seamless smart TV experience, look at another brand or budget about a hundred more in order to get all the adapters and cords.

Reviews.Title: External Features
Reviews.Author: ThomasFukushima
Reviews.Content: Good external connection features, i.e., Wiifi and good picture qualities.  Quality & features/price considered superior.Negatives: Must select aspect ratio for each channel.  Does not appear to memorize aspect ratio for each channel selection.  Convoluted way to view the channel selection.Selected unit based on specification features and potential reliability.

Reviews.Title: Good No-Frills Set
Reviews.Author: John T. Shea
Reviews.Content: There is only so much I expect from a 42' TV that only costs $450, and I can happily say that this set easily exceeds them. The picture quality is excellent, and the unit itself is sleek and thin. If you are looking for features such as 3D and easy Internet connectivity you would probably do well to look elsewhere (read; spend more $), but if you are looking for a basic, high-quality set, you will be more than pleased with this television.

Reviews.Title: No Audio out...
Reviews.Author: Monkey 5
Reviews.Content: I went to hook this TV up and noticed I could not get the TV to sync up with DVD player and got an Echo with my stereo on.  that was a disappointment.  Also I could not get the TV to play the Audio from my computer - So I put my old TV back up and the computer worked fine along with the stereo.  If I bought the TV from a store, I would have taken it back even though the picture is really good.  But I didn't want to mail it back and wait again for another as it was a Christmas gift - I just put it down stairs where we don't have a stereo.  It should work.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic TC-L47E5 = Wonderful
Reviews.Author: Stephen S
Reviews.Content: This review is actually for the TC-L47E5. Purchased directly from Panasonic, since it was not yet available from Amazon.  We are thrilled with our 47" Panasonic. Much better than our older 720P Toshiba LCD which had developed a slight cloud across the center of the screen.  Still playing with the features, but so far so good.  Picture quality is fantastic.  We have our FiOS router inside our entertainment center, so we run ethernet to the TV; no need for wireless for us.  It is very nice to have the option of using the Viera Android App to control the TV (via its connection to our home network).  We connected coax to the TV to view the non-scrambled FiOS channels as well as the HDMI cable from the Set Top Box to one of the four HDMI inputs on the TV to view all FiOS content. Both input methods work perfectly.  It is great to be able to pop the SD card out of our video (or still) camera and view the content via the SD slot on the TV without the need to connect the camera via cables. TV has one SD slot and two USB slots; accessible from the back - not a big issue for us, but easier access from the front might be helpful to some people. Multiple video and audio formats are supported for playback directly by the TV.  Have setup DLNA access for the TV from our home computer system. Works well, but not a critical feature for us, since we have an HDMI connection from the computer to the TV. (DLNA does give us the option of perhaps moving the PC to a different room at some point...)  Minor complaints:  1) Audio output is optical only. Why not include analog out and/or a headphone jack???  [Optical output only seems to be the way the big TVs are going.] There are converters that will convert the optical signal to analog (price for stereo is not too bad, but full theater is higher than I want to spend for a converter). I am looking at spending a bit more and purchasing a Panasonic home theater system which includes the "Audio Return Channel" feature which will transfer audio from the TV to the audio system via the HDMI cable.  2) Would have liked an additional input or two; perhaps available from the front without having to reach behind the TV to get to them. [TV has 4 HDMI inputs and a single non-HDMI input which can be used for AV or Component input via the included adapter. All inputs are accessible from the left side (as one is facing the screen) rear of the TV.  3) There is an "Intelligent Audio" feature which is supposed to normalize the volume across the input channels. We turned this on, but the audio from the FiOS Set Top Box comes out louder than the other input channels. (I have tried adjusting the STB volume; this seems to change the level for the audio out jacks on the STB, but not on the HDMI output...)  4) My wife is shopping for a new entertainment center to fit our larger TV. (I prefer the less expensive pedestal option...)  5) TV media player does not have an option to play all of the video on the SD card from our camcorder from one request - we can request play of at most one folder at a time; which for us is day-by-day playback. I would love an option to "Play All".  We had been considering this against the Panasonic TC-L47E50. Based on a side-by-side comparison the only difference appeared to be the suite of available internet apps; which was not important to us, since we have a PC connected to the TV for internet access. We later learned that the refresh rate (not included in the side-by-side comparison) is 2x greater on the E50 vs. the E5. So far we have not seen any issues due to the lower refresh rate.

Reviews.Title: holy @%^%$E$$ WOW!
Reviews.Author: 1sttimebuyer
Reviews.Content: What an awesome tv. we bought this as a gift.  I wish I bought one for myself but didn't cause just got a tv.I would hghly recommond this to anyone

Reviews.Title: Excellent picture quality.
Reviews.Author: Brian
Reviews.Content: Beautiful picture and the perfect centerpiece of a home entertainment system for a small room. Rating is based on picture quality and overall satisfaction. A stereo system handles the sound for me, so I do not know how well the native sound on this TV compares to others of its type.

Reviews.Title: The Perfect TV.
Reviews.Author: Austin Somlo
